did.abstract: This collection consists of two postcard albums containing photographic postcards printed by the Brooklyn Daily Eagle during the early 20th century. The postcards depict various Brooklyn street and neighborhood scenes, landscapes, parks, monuments, docks and ships, municipal buildings, homes, schools, churches, and businesses, as well as scenes from theatrical productions in New York and portraits of prominent New York residents and celebrities.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Brooklyn Eagle was a daily newspaper that was published in Brooklyn for over 114 years. Founded in 1841 by Isaac van Anden and Henry Cruse Murphy, the newspaper was originally named the Brooklyn Eagle and King's County Democrat. In 1850, the name was changed to the Brooklyn Daily Eagle. By the early 1860s, the newspaper had become one of the most widely read papers in the United States. In 1938, the newspaper underwent another name change when it became the Brooklyn Eagle. Frank D. Schroth bought the paper in 1940 and continued to publish it until 1955 when the Eagle ceased publication during a lengthy strike by the New York Newspaper Guild. Between 1960 and 1963, the Eagle once again resumed publication, this time as a weekly paper (though for a short time as a daily). The run was short-lived and the Brooklyn Eagle office closed in December 1963. In 1996, J. Dozier Hasty, the owner and publisher of Brooklyn Heights Press, purchased the Eagle's name and logo and began to publish the Brooklyn Daily Eagle & Daily Bulletin. As of 2011, the Brooklyn Daily Eagle & Daily Bulletin remains a daily newspaper, published five days per week.
